hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Baraa ibn Azib: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ appointed Abdullah ibn Jubair over the archers on the day of Uhud, and they were fifty men. He placed them in a position and said: If you see us being taken away by the birds (i.e., defeated and killed), do not leave your position until I send to you. And if you see us having defeated the people and trampled them, do not leave your position until I send to you. Allah gave them victory, but the companions of Abdullah ibn Jubair said: The booty! The booty! Your companions have appeared victorious, what are you waiting for? Abdullah ibn Jubair said: Did you forget what the Messenger of Allah ﷺ commanded you?

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Shayban ibn Farrukh, from Abu Hilal, from Qatada who said: The last of the companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) to die in Medina was Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him), in Kufa was Ibn Abi Awfa, and in Basra was Anas ibn Malik. And I heard Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shaybah saying: Anas ibn Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) died in the year ninety-three on a Friday. Ibn Abi Asim said: Ibn Abi Awfa died in the year eighty-six and Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) in the year seventy-eight. And after Jabir from among the Companions of the Messenger in Medina died Abdullah ibn Ja'far, Abdullah ibn Amir ibn Rabi'ah, As-Sa'ib ibn Yazid, and Sahl ibn Sa'd in the year ninety-one. And the last to die in Medina from among the Companions of the Messenger were As-Sa'ib ibn Yazid and Sahl ibn Sa'd who died in the year ninety-one.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Muhammad ibn Umar ibn Ali ibn Ata ibn Muqaddam, from Ibrahim ibn Habib ibn Ash-Shahid, from his father, from Amr ibn Dinar, from Jabir ibn Abdullah ibn Amr ibn Haram Al-Ansari who said: My father ordered khazira (a type of food) to be made, then I carried it to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was in his house. He said: What is this, O Jabir, is this meat? I said: No, O Messenger of Allah, but it is khazira that my father ordered to be made, and then he ordered me to carry it to you. Then I returned to my father and he said: Did you see the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)? I said: Yes. He said: What did he say to you? I said: He said to me: Is this meat, O Jabir? He said: Perhaps the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) has a craving for meat. So he stood up to a domestic animal of his and slaughtered it, then skinned it, then ordered it to be roasted, then he ordered me to carry it to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and he was sitting in his gathering. He said to me: What is this, O Jabir? I said: I returned to my father and he asked me what did the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say to you? I said: He said: Is this meat, O Jabir? So my father said: Perhaps the Messenger of Allah craved meat, so he stood up to a domestic animal of his and slaughtered it, then ordered it to be roasted, then ordered me to carry it to you, O Messenger of Allah. So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: May Allah reward the Ansar with goodness on our behalf, and especially Abdullah ibn Amr and Sa'd ibn Ubadah (may Allah be pleased with them).

He said: There is no power and no strength except with Allah.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Bakr ibn Abi Shaybah, from Abdullah ibn Numayr, from Muhammad ibn Ishaq, from Ya'qub ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Ash-hab, from Umm Sa'id bint Sa'd ibn Ubadah (may Allah be pleased with her) who said: Sa'id ibn Sa'd ibn Ubadah was struck with paralysis, so the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) came to visit him along with Abd ar-Rahman ibn Awf, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, and Abdullah ibn Mas'ud. He saw him unconscious, so he said: Has he died? They said: No, O Messenger of Allah. So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) wept. When the people saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) weeping, they wept. He said: Do you not hear? Indeed Allah does not punish for the tears of the eye nor for the grief of the heart, but He punishes or shows mercy for this - and he pointed to his tongue.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Numayr from Ibn Abi Ubaydah from his father from Al-A'mash from Abu Ishaq from Amr ibn Shurahbil from An-Nu'man ibn Bashir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: There were three men walking after a rain - and he mentioned the hadith in full. [The hadith describes three men from Bani Israel - a leper, a bald man, and a blind man - who were each tested by an angel. The leper and bald man failed the test by being ungrateful and denying Allah's blessings, while the blind man passed by being grateful and generous]. The hadith is narrated through multiple chains including: Ibn Numayr from Ubaydullah ibn Musa from Israel from Abu Ishaq from a man from Bajilah from An-Nu'man; Ibn Numayr from Ismail ibn Abd al-Karim As-San'ani from Abd as-Samad ibn Ma'qil from Wahb ibn Munabbih from An-Nu'man; Ibn Numayr from Ishaq ibn Sulayman Ad-Dari from Abu Sinan from Abu Ishaq from An-Nu'man; and Hammad ibn Salamah from Simak from An-Nu'man, narrated to us by Ayyub Al-Wazzan from Yahya ibn As-Sakan from Hammad.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ya'qub ibn Humayd, from Abd al-Aziz ibn Muhammad, from Yazid ibn Abdullah ibn Al-Had, from Muhammad ibn Ka'b who said: Abdullah ibn Unays (may Allah be pleased with him) said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said one day: Who will deal with Khalid ibn Nubayh, a man from Hudhayl? - and he was at that time in Arafah. So Abdullah (may Allah be pleased with him) said: I will, O Messenger of Allah, describe him to me. He said: If you saw him you would be frightened. So I said: By the One who honored you, I have never been frightened of anything. So I went out until I met him in the mountains of Arafah before the sun set. Ibn Unays (may Allah be pleased with him) said: So I encountered fear from him, and I knew when I was frightened of him that he was the one the Prophet (peace be upon him) spoke of. He said: Who is the man? I said: One seeking a need, so is there lodging? He said: Yes, so follow me. So I went out following him, and I prayed Asr two brief rak'ahs, fearing that he would see me, then I followed him and struck him with the sword. Then I went out until I covered the mountain, and I stayed until the people left me alone, then I went out until I arrived in Medina to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and I informed him of the news. Muhammad ibn Ka'b (may Allah be pleased with him) said: So the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) gave me a staff and said: Carry this staff with you until you meet me with it on the Day of Resurrection - and the fewest people on that day will be those buried with staffs. Muhammad ibn Ka'b said: So when Abdullah ibn Unays (may Allah be pleased with him) died, he ordered it to be placed on his stomach, and he was shrouded over it and buried with it.
